body: `register-pepper-plugins` need not be proxied, its already handled by the content layer of [chromium](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/codesearch#chromium/src/content/common/pepper_plugin_list.cc&sq=package:chromium&l=144&rcl=1435750164) and the ppapi binary interfaces are already present in `Electron`. So there should be no problem loading trusted plugins. I didnt try loading complex plugins, just a few from `nacl_sdk` examples.

There is some ground work left on `Electron` to get widevine work successfully, we need to override `ContentRendererClient::AddKeySystems` which registers the key systems used to select appropriate cdm. You can check `ChromeContentRendererClient::AddKeySystems` for [usage](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/codesearch#chromium/src/chrome/renderer/chrome_content_renderer_client.cc&sq=package:chromium&rcl=1436052378&l=1501)

Thanks @deepak1556 that really helps. This is my first attempt at working with a c/c++ based project so progress is slow.

I'd taken the [list of supported Chrome command line switches](https://github.com/atom/electron/blob/master/docs/api/chrome-command-line-switches.md) as exlusive. I now understand that they're not and that any switches under [content](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/codesearch#chromium/src/content/) should also be available.

I will start experimenting in `AtomRendererClient` with the code from `ChromeContentRendererClient::AddKeySystems` and see where I get to as this should be testable with the widevine plugin that is distributed with Chrome 43.
@simongregory any update on this? I as well am interested in using Widevine (and potentially other pepper based EME key systems). Let me know if there is anything I can help out with.

I too am curious about the state of this.  The hope is Electron could provide a base to create a portable and customizable base for streaming Netflix.  I am disappointed with the limited options avaialbe for my Arch Linux based Kodi HTPC.

I have tried introducing the `AddKeySystems` code from Chrome that @deepak1556 mentioned. Found it really slow as I don't know enough C. Likely to be September until I've the time to take another look - but it's still on my backlog.
Have you ever tried the instead of the pepper-plugin using the [chromium-widevine](http://www.slackware.com/~alien/slackbuilds/chromium-widevine-plugin/) one?
CEF added support for this here https://bitbucket.org/chromiumembedded/cef/commits/b97781424875fcde970c1a2b440acecc86683ad3 just as a starting point if anyone wants to take this.
Thanks @FWeinb that change set is really helpful. Progress wise this has been picked up again and is slowly moving forward.
@simongregory Have you made any interesting progress?

Yes, I've got playback working on a Mac in a _edited_ version of this [Electron branch](https://github.com/simongregory/electron/tree/widevine-cdm) with a custom patch to Brightray and using this [libchromiumcontent branch](https://github.com/simongregory/libchromiumcontent/tree/atom-with-widevine).

This was done by ignoring the Widevine related switches in [atom_content_client.cc](https://github.com/simongregory/electron/blob/widevine-cdm/atom/app/atom_content_client.cc#L163) to allow plugin to load directly (or rather be treated as Linux on a Mac).

For licensing reasons the Widevine plugin needs to loaded via the widevinecdmadapter.plugin so we are currently working towards integration of chromes component update mechanism. This affects only the Windows and Mac platform so I would expect the linux version to work as is (however I haven't checked).  

Brightray is modified in Electrons `vendor/brightray/brightray.gyp`  by adding the following at line 122:

```
'<(libchromiumcontent_dir)/libcdm_renderer.a',
'<(libchromiumcontent_dir)/libcomponent_updater.a',
```

@simongregory Ok awesome! Any chance you could comment on this thread when you have the update mechanism working?

On a related note, anything that would make your branches un-mergeable with the main electron/brightray repos?
Will this work on arm devices like the raspberry pi or is there something else needed to get that working there.

EDIT 2: Here are the only 2 causes generating the errors right now:
- [ ] Neither `GOOGLE_CHROME_BUILD` nor `CHROMIUM_BUILD` are defined
- [x] Missing `));` at https://github.com/simongregory/electron/blob/widevine-cdm/chromium_src/chrome/renderer/media/chrome_key_systems.cc#L43-L47 is generating all those errors.
- [x] `ChromeViewHostMsg_IsInternalPluginAvailableForMimeType` has a constructor for 4 args, 3 being passed right now. Add `additional_param_values` at the 4 args and it works.

@romaincointepas I just pulled your branch and got it to build, but it doesn't look widevine playback is working. 

These are the steps I followed to do the build:

```
# checkout the electron branch w/ EME support
git clone --recursive git@github.com:romaincointepas/electron.git

# build libchromiumcontent
cd electron/vendor/brightray/vendor/libchromiumcontent
./script/bootstrap -v
./script/update -t x64
./script/build -t x64
./script/create-dist

# move libchromiumcontent zips to the right spot
mkdir -p osx/x64/464aff2398f619b1d4d91b9187de69803919dca2
cp libchromiumcontent.zip osx/x64/464aff2398f619b1d4d91b9187de69803919dca2/
cp libchromiumcontent-static.zip osx/x64/464aff2398f619b1d4d91b9187de69803919dca2
cd ../../../../

# add the widevinecdmadpater
cp ~/Library/Application\ Support/Google/Chrome/WidevineCDM/1.4.8.824/_platform_specific/mac_x64/widevinecdmadapter.plugin vendor/brightray/vendor/download/libchromiumcontent/shared_library

# trigger the build
./script/bootstrap.py -v -u file://`pwd`/vendor/brightray/vendor/libchromiumcontent
./script/build.py -c D
```

Here's how i'm testing for widevine support:

```
 var video = document.createElement('video');
 video.canPlayType('video/mp4; codecs="avc1.640028', 'com.widevine.alpha');
// returns "" on electron, chrome it returns "probably"
```

Please let me know what i'm missing. Thanks for effort, I'm super excited to get this working!

Again, it's @simongregory and @natgolov's work, I just happen to be less busy.

@massimopalmieri Follow @rewiredpictures step called `# add the widevinecdmadpater` before building, then follow instructions below.

@rewiredpictures I've copied both `widevinecdmadapter.plugin` and `libwidevinecdm.dylib` from the Google `Application Support/` location to a `plugins` folder in my app, then in main.js I added:

```
widevine_adapter_path = path.join __dirname, '../plugins/widevinecdmadapter.plugin'
app.commandLine.appendSwitch 'register-pepper-plugins', "#{widevine_adapter_path};application/x-ppapi-widevine-cdm"
```

Also, don't forget to add `plugins: true` to the `BrowserWindow` or the `plugins` attribute to the `webview` when necessary.

You can check if the plugin is loaded by typing `navigator.plugins` in the dev tools console.
thanks @romaincointepas, that worked
@rewiredpictures try with `navigator.requestMediaKeySystemAccess('com.widevine.alpha', [{contentType: 'video/mp4; codecs="avc1.4d401e"'}])` to test for widevine support, `canPlayType` was deprecated

I've now tried the Electron release binary on OS X 10.11.2 (verified with Shaka Player) and 10.9.5 (verified with Ep1 Series1 of Breaking Bad on Netflix UK and Shaka) without issue.  

That's using a Widevine CDM Adapter versioned at 47.0.2526.106 and a WidevineCDM versioned at 1.4.8.866. In instances where Shaka is expected to be global, I had to include `nodeIntegration: false` in the `webPreferences` hash when instantiating the BrowserWindow. In that case, Shaka seems to be checking for the existence of things like `require`, which are on the window in Electron.

Both `electron` and `electron-prebuilt` are the same package. You should use `electron` as the other is deprecated and occasionally (and currently) outdated.

To use beta releases you will want to install `electron@beta` though. IE `npm install electron@beta --save-dev`.
